header_summary: Salvatore Ingala proposes improvements to MATT, including a new opcode and parameter modifications. The discussion on inscription spam emphasizes the challenges and the need for a comprehensive solution. Enabling full-replace-by-fee (full-rbf) by default is suggested as a solution to address node relaying issues. A scheme for multipath payments in the `keysend` protocol is proposed, and Lightning specification meeting transcripts are now available publicly. Discussions on Bitcoin network policies cover fee determination, channel jamming, and transaction efficiency.

recent_posts.title: Concrete MATT opcodes
recent_posts.summary:
- Salvatore Ingala has presented a proposal for MATT's core opcode, making it functionally complete.
- The proposal includes replacing OP_CHECK{IN, OUT}CONTRACTVERIFY with OP_CHECKCONTRACTVERIFY and introducing a flags parameter.
- The new opcode, along with OP_CAT, achieves the full generality of MATT, with potential for additional opcodes.

recent_posts.title: Concern about "Inscriptions".
recent_posts.summary:
- Inscriptions in the Bitcoin network can be detected and standardized more easily than spam transactions.
- Constant updates would be required to prevent propagation of inscriptions, while pro-inscription users only need to convince others to update.
- Economic factors and community decisions play a crucial role in preventing inscription spam attacks.

recent_posts.title: Pull-req to enable Full-RBF by default
recent_posts.summary:
- The author proposes enabling full-replace-by-fee (full-rbf) by default in Bitcoin Core.
- Block explorers, nodes, and wallets have adopted full-rbf, but only a minority of nodes relay it.
- The author suggests enabling full-rbf by default to address the issue and eventually removing BIP125 code.

recent_posts.title: Multipath Keysend
recent_posts.summary:
- ZmnSCPxj proposes a multipath `keysend` scheme that ensures the receiver claims the payment after all parts arrive.
- The scheme involves embedding a preimage as TLV 5482373484 in the `keysend`, generating a payment hash, and XORing preimages.
- The receiver's support for multipath `keysend` can be detected through error responses or MPP timeout.

recent_posts.title: Specification Meeting Transcripts
recent_posts.summary:
- Our team has diligently recorded and transcribed specification meetings since the beginning of the year.
- Transcripts of these meetings are now available to everyone at [https://btctranscripts.com/lightning-specification].
- Gurwinder at Chaincode has reviewed and ensured the accuracy of the transcripts, maintaining high quality.

recent_posts.title: LN Summit 2023 Notes
recent_posts.summary:
- The email thread discussed Bitcoin network policies and potential solutions to address issues.
- Topics included the "top of mempool" assumption, lightning unilateral closes, zero-fee transactions, and trimmed HTLCs.
- A hybrid approach to channel jamming mitigation and market dynamics for fee regulation were proposed.

active_posts.title: Standardisation of an unstructured taproot annex
active_posts.summary:
- The taproot annex is currently consensus valid but non-standard, with discussions on standardization.
- In the meantime, a proposal suggests allowing non-structured annexes with immediate utilization and future flexibility.
- This approach offers chainspace efficiency and broadens the scope while preserving the possibility of future structure.

active_posts.title: Blinded 2-party Musig2
active_posts.summary:
- The implementation of a blinded version of 2-of-2 Schnorr Musig2 for statechains is discussed.
- A server, referred to as party 1, is fully blinded to certain information in the implementation.
- The security in blinded statechains relies on trusting the statechain server and verifying signatures client-side.

active_posts.title: On the experiment of the Bitcoin Contracting Primitives WG and marking this community process "up for grabs"
active_posts.summary:
- Last year, a new community process was introduced to specify covenants, addressing consensus development issues.
- Initiatives included the bitcoin-inquisition fork, archiving proposals, and establishing the Bitcoin Contracting Primitives Working Group.
- The author, focused on Lightning development, encouraged continued efforts in covenant changes proposals.

active_posts.title: HTLC Endorsement for Jamming Mitigation
active_posts.summary:
- The email discusses channel jamming updates and announces the next call on May 1st.
- The group plans to collect data regarding HTLC endorsement and local reputation tracking for jamming mitigation.
- They propose a reputation scheme and endorse HTLCs as the first step in mitigating channel jams.

active_posts.title: Potential vulnerability in Lightning backends: BOLT-11 "payment hash" does not commit to payment!
active_posts.summary:
- LNbits team patched an exploit that allowed attackers to create balances through manipulated invoices.
- Similar exploits may be possible in other Lightning applications related to custodial wallets and payment processors.
- The incident highlights the need for developers to be proactive in addressing vulnerabilities in Lightning applications.

active_posts.title: Blinded Paths Doom Scenario
active_posts.summary:
- Blinded paths in the Lightning Network offer privacy benefits for receiving nodes.
- Payments can only be made through given paths, potentially limiting destination options.
- Concerns raised about compromising privacy and the trade-off between receiver privacy and compliance.
